articles.headline: How Rhubarb Conquered Germany, Then the World
articles.snippet: A tongue-twisting rap by a Berlin duo has spotlighted Germans’ love of their springtime produce. Now if only they could find a rhyme for asparagus.
articles.abstract: A tongue-twisting rap by a Berlin duo has spotlighted Germans’ love of their springtime produce. Now if only they could find a rhyme for asparagus.
articles.lead_paragraph: In the past month, millions of people have found themselves stumbling through the contorted and catchy syllables of a song about, of all things, a woman named Barbara and some rhubarb-loving barbarians who drink beer while getting their beards barbered. In German.

articles.headline: Google’s A.I. Search Leaves Publishers Scrambling
articles.snippet: Since Google overhauled its search engine, publishers have tried to assess the danger to their brittle business models while calling for government intervention.
articles.abstract: Since Google overhauled its search engine, publishers have tried to assess the danger to their brittle business models while calling for government intervention.
articles.lead_paragraph: When Frank Pine searched Google for a link to a news article two months ago, he encountered paragraphs generated by artificial intelligence about the topic at the top of his results. To see what he wanted, he had to scroll past them.
articles.byline: By Nico Grant and Katie Robertson

articles.headline: Democrats Push Biden to Make Trump’s Felonies a Top 2024 Issue
articles.snippet: Interviews with dozens of Democrats reveal a party hungry to tell voters that Donald Trump’s conviction makes him unfit for office, and hopeful that President Biden will lead the way.
articles.abstract: Interviews with dozens of Democrats reveal a party hungry to tell voters that Donald Trump’s conviction makes him unfit for office, and hopeful that President Biden will lead the way.
articles.lead_paragraph: Now that former President Donald J. Trump is a convicted criminal, the Democratic Party finds itself wrestling with a choice that will help define this year’s presidential race: Should it try to push his felonies to the center of the election?
articles.byline: By Reid J. Epstein and Nicholas Nehamas

articles.headline: South African Voters Reject the Party That Freed Them From Apartheid
articles.snippet: The African National Congress received less than 50 percent of the national vote for the first time since gaining power 30 years ago, setting the nation on an uncharted course.
articles.abstract: The African National Congress received less than 50 percent of the national vote for the first time since gaining power 30 years ago, setting the nation on an uncharted course.
articles.lead_paragraph: The African National Congress lost its political monopoly on South Africa after election results on Saturday showed that with almost all of the votes counted, the party had received only about 40 percent, falling short of winning an absolute majority for the first time since vanquishing Africa’s last white-led regime 30 years ago.

articles.headline: How a Retirement Withdrawal Can Lead to a Perjury Conviction
articles.snippet: A prominent lawyer was recently sentenced to home confinement for falsely claiming hardship to withdraw funds. How desperate must you be to take money out?
articles.abstract: A prominent lawyer was recently sentenced to home confinement for falsely claiming hardship to withdraw funds. How desperate must you be to take money out?
articles.lead_paragraph: Sometimes, it’s illegal to spend money that you set aside for yourself.

articles.headline: After Biden’s Push for Truce, Netanyahu Calls Israel’s War Plans Unchanged
articles.snippet: The timing of the remarks seemed to rebuff the president’s hopes for a speedy end to the war. But some analysts said the prime minister was aiming at domestic supporters, not the White House.
articles.abstract: The timing of the remarks seemed to rebuff the president’s hopes for a speedy end to the war. But some analysts said the prime minister was aiming at domestic supporters, not the White House.
articles.lead_paragraph: A day after President Biden called on Israel and Hamas to reach a truce, declaring that it was “time for this war to end,” Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu on Saturday reiterated that Israel would not agree to a permanent cease-fire in Gaza as long as Hamas still retains governing and military power.

articles.headline: The Internet’s Final Frontier: Remote Amazon Tribes
articles.snippet: Elon Musk’s Starlink has connected an isolated tribe to the outside world — and divided it from within.
articles.abstract: Elon Musk’s Starlink has connected an isolated tribe to the outside world — and divided it from within.
articles.lead_paragraph: As the speeches dragged on, eyes drifted to screens. Teenagers scrolled Instagram. One man texted his girlfriend. And men crowded around a phone streaming a soccer match while the group’s first female leader spoke.
articles.byline: By Jack Nicas and Victor Moriyama

articles.headline: The Floating Traffic Jam That Freaked Us All Out
articles.snippet: The coronavirus pandemic schooled the world in the essential role of global supply chains. Have we learned anything from it?
articles.abstract: The coronavirus pandemic schooled the world in the essential role of global supply chains. Have we learned anything from it?
articles.lead_paragraph: Southern California appeared to be under siege from a blockade.

articles.headline: They Spent Their Life Savings on Life Coaching
articles.snippet: Some people who wanted to improve their lives and careers through coaching found themselves trapped in what they described as a pyramid scheme.
articles.abstract: Some people who wanted to improve their lives and careers through coaching found themselves trapped in what they described as a pyramid scheme.
articles.lead_paragraph: To an outsider, Billiejo Mullett is someone who has her head firmly screwed on. She’s smart and educated — a registered nurse who works for a medical insurance provider — and balances her career with a busy family life.

articles.headline: A Felon in the Oval Office Would Test the American System
articles.snippet: Some are wondering how the Constitution’s checks and balances, meant to hold presidents accountable, would work if the next president elected were already a felon.
articles.abstract: Some are wondering how the Constitution’s checks and balances, meant to hold presidents accountable, would work if the next president elected were already a felon.
articles.lead_paragraph: The revolutionary hero Patrick Henry knew this day would come. He might not have anticipated all the particulars, such as the porn actress in the hotel room and the illicit payoff to keep her quiet. But he feared that eventually a criminal might occupy the presidency and use his powers to thwart anyone who sought to hold him accountable. “Away with your president,” he declared, “we shall have a king.”

articles.headline: Hunter Biden to Go on Trial in Gun Case, Days After Trump Was Convicted
articles.snippet: On Monday in Delaware, one of two trials will begin in which President Biden’s son will defend himself during a presidential election year.
articles.abstract: On Monday in Delaware, one of two trials will begin in which President Biden’s son will defend himself during a presidential election year.
articles.lead_paragraph: Follow our live updates of Hunter Biden’s trial in a gun case.

articles.headline: Netanyahu May Face a Choice Between a Truce and His Government’s Survival
articles.snippet: The Israeli prime minister has been put on the spot by President Biden’s announcement outlining a proposal for a truce.
articles.abstract: The Israeli prime minister has been put on the spot by President Biden’s announcement outlining a proposal for a truce.
articles.lead_paragraph: For months, Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu of Israel has refused to offer a timeline for ending the war against Hamas in Gaza, a stance his critics see as a political tactic. But he has been put on the spot by President Biden’s announcement outlining a proposal for a truce.

articles.headline: A Surging Hard Right in Europe Stumbles Over Its Own Divisions
articles.snippet: Elections starting this week for the European Parliament could leave far-right parties with more power than ever, but also expose the fissures among them.
articles.abstract: Elections starting this week for the European Parliament could leave far-right parties with more power than ever, but also expose the fissures among them.
articles.lead_paragraph: Nationalists are surging and expected to make big gains when voters from 27 nations cast ballots starting this week for the European Parliament. But the prospect of success is already raising the question among far-right parties of how far is too far.

articles.headline: Liberals Find a TV Prescription for Election Jitters: Monday Nights
articles.snippet: Once a week, Rachel Maddow and Jon Stewart are luring viewers back to basic cable.
articles.abstract: Once a week, Rachel Maddow and Jon Stewart are luring viewers back to basic cable.
articles.lead_paragraph: Liberal TV viewers have a new mantra: T.G.I.M.!
articles.byline: By Michael M. Grynbaum and John Koblin

articles.headline: Abnormally Dry Canada Taps U.S. Energy, Reversing Usual Flow
articles.snippet: Lower-than-normal rain and snow have reduced Canada’s hydropower production, raising worries in the industry about the effects of climate change.
articles.abstract: Lower-than-normal rain and snow have reduced Canada’s hydropower production, raising worries in the industry about the effects of climate change.
articles.lead_paragraph: In February, the United States did something that it had not done in many years — the country sent more electricity to Canada than it received from its northern neighbor. Then, in March, U.S. electricity exports to Canada climbed even more, reaching their highest level since at least 2010.
articles.byline: By Ivan Penn and Ruth Fremson

articles.headline: Biden Is Expected to Sign Order Letting Him Seal Border With Mexico
articles.snippet: The move, expected on Tuesday, would allow the president to temporarily close the border and suspend longtime protections for asylum seekers in the United States.
articles.abstract: The move, expected on Tuesday, would allow the president to temporarily close the border and suspend longtime protections for asylum seekers in the United States.
articles.lead_paragraph: President Biden is expected to sign an executive order on Tuesday allowing him to temporarily seal the U.S. border with Mexico to migrants when crossings surge, a move that would suspend longtime protections for asylum seekers in the United States.
articles.byline: By Hamed Aleaziz and Zolan Kanno-Youngs

articles.headline: Holocaust Museums Debate What to Say About the Israel-Hamas War
articles.snippet: Students are bringing up antisemitic tropes and asking survivors and docents: What is Palestine? Is there a genocide in Gaza?
articles.abstract: Students are bringing up antisemitic tropes and asking survivors and docents: What is Palestine? Is there a genocide in Gaza?
articles.lead_paragraph: At a Holocaust museum in Atlanta, staff members had typically ended their tours by saying that many survivors of the death camps immigrated to Palestine.
articles.byline: By Dana Goldstein and Marc Tracy

articles.headline: Washington Post Newsroom Reels From Its Editor’s Sudden Exit
articles.snippet: Sally Buzbee, who has been editor of The Washington Post since 2021, chafed at a major reorganization by the newspaper’s chief executive.
articles.abstract: Sally Buzbee, who has been editor of The Washington Post since 2021, chafed at a major reorganization by the newspaper’s chief executive.
articles.lead_paragraph: On Sunday night, minutes after Will Lewis, the chief executive of The Washington Post, informed employees that the newspaper’s executive editor, Sally Buzbee, was being replaced, managers gathered on a conference call to hear from their boss one last time.
articles.byline: By Benjamin Mullin and Katie Robertson

articles.headline: Electric Cars Are Suddenly Becoming Affordable
articles.snippet: More efficient manufacturing, falling battery costs and intense competition are lowering sticker prices for battery-powered models to within striking distance of gasoline cars.
articles.abstract: More efficient manufacturing, falling battery costs and intense competition are lowering sticker prices for battery-powered models to within striking distance of gasoline cars.
articles.lead_paragraph: Alex Lawrence, a dealer in Salt Lake City who specializes in used electric cars, has seen a change over the last year in the kinds of customers who are coming into his showroom. They used to be well-heeled professionals who could drop $70,000 on a Rivian luxury pickup truck.

articles.headline: Car Deals Vanished During the Pandemic. They’re Coming Back.
articles.snippet: Automakers and dealers are starting to offer discounts, low-interest loans and other incentives to lure buyers as the supply of cars grows.
articles.abstract: Automakers and dealers are starting to offer discounts, low-interest loans and other incentives to lure buyers as the supply of cars grows.
articles.lead_paragraph: For much of the last four years, automakers and their dealers had so few cars to sell — and demand was so strong — that they could command high prices. Those days are over, and hefty discounts are starting a comeback.

articles.headline: Feeling Consumers’ Pain, Retailers Bring Back Discounts
articles.snippet: The pandemic shopping boom led many stores and brands to widen profit margins by charging more. Now value is the watchword as shoppers grow choosier.
articles.abstract: The pandemic shopping boom led many stores and brands to widen profit margins by charging more. Now value is the watchword as shoppers grow choosier.
articles.lead_paragraph: U.S. consumers, fatigued by a three-year bout of inflation, want lower prices. And large retailers that have increased prices, partly to contend with their own rising costs, appear to be responding to customer concerns — to an extent.
articles.byline: By Talmon Joseph Smith and Jordyn Holman
